'''''Agaricus brunneofibrillosus''''' is a [[mushroom]] in the family [[Agaricaceae]]. It has a medium to dark brown [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] up to {{convert|6|cm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter with brownish fibrillose scales that darken in age. The tightly-packed [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are initially cream colored before becoming pinkish, [[lilac (color)|lilac]]-gray, and finally brownish as the [[spore]]s mature.  The stout [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is enlarged to bulbous at the base which has one or more brown bands, and a white, membranous [[annulus (mycology)|ring]]. The mushroom is [[edible mushroom|edible]], and has a pleasant odor similar to [[button mushrooms]], and tastes similar to ''[[Agaricus bisporus]]'' when cooked.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}

==Systematics==

This species was first studied by [[Rick Kerrigan]], who studied collections from the California coast,<ref name="Kerrigan1986">Kerrigan RW. (1986). ''The Agaricales (Gilled Fungi) of California. 6. Agaricaceae.'' Mad River Press.</ref> and identified the collections as belonging to ''Agaricus fuscofibrillosus'' ([[F.H. Møller]]) [[Albert Pilát|Pilát]], a species originally described from northern and central Europe.<ref name="Møller 1950"/><ref name="Pilát 1951"/> Later investigation by Kerrigan revealed that the California population was a different species from the European one, and in fact, belonged to a different subsection of ''Agaricus'' entirely. In 2016, as part of a larger monograph on the ''Agaricus'' species of North America, Kerrigan described ''Agaricus brunneofibrillosus'' as a separate species. The [[specific name (botany)|epithet]] ''brunneofibrillosus'' refers to the brown color and fibrillose texture of the [[pileus (mycology)|pileus]], as well as the distinction from ''A. fuscofibrillosus''.<ref name="Kerrigan2016"/>

European ''Agaricus fuscofibrillosus'' is now treated as a synonym for ''[[Agaricus langei]]''.<ref name="LA Parra"/>

==Description==
The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is initially convex before flattening out, and reaches a diameter of {{convert|4|–|15|cm|in|abbr=on}}. The cap surface is dry, smooth, reddish-brown to coco-brown with silky fibrils or sometimes with flattened scales and often has a slight [[umbo (mycology)|umbo]]. In maturity, the fibrils usually darken to walnut brown.  The flesh is light brown and does not change color in [[Potassium hydroxide|KOH]]. When bruised or injured, the flesh turns bright red within 30 seconds, and later fades to brown. The odor of crushed flesh is mild and mushroomy.

The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are initially cream colored to pale pinkish or pinkish-gray before becoming brown, then dark chocolate-brown when the spores mature. In maturity, the gills are free from attachment to the stem, packed close together, with little intervening space between them. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|4|–|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, and {{convert|1.5|–|2.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick, usually with an enlarged or bulbous base that has one or more coca-brown colored bands. Firm, smooth, and lacking the scales found on the cap, the stem is colored white or discolors bright red or dingy brownish in age or after handling.  The [[partial veil]] is membranous, white, and forms a thin skirt-like [[annulus (mycology)|ring]] on the upper portion of the stem.

[[Spore print]]s are dark chocolate brown. The smooth, thick-walled [[spore]]s are [[wikt:elliptical|elliptical]], and typically measure 5–6.5 by 3.5-4 [[micrometre|μm]].  [[Cystidia]] on the gill edge (cheilocystidia) are scattered, club-shaped to cylindric and have dimensions of up to 22 by 7 μm.

[[File:Agaricus fuscofibrillosus spores 1000x.JPG|thumb|Spores 1000x]]

===Similar species===
''[[Agaricus amicosus]]'' is similar to and a close relative of ''A. brunneofibrillosus''.<ref name="Kerrigan2016"/> It differs considerably in geography, however, being endemic to [[spruce]] and [[fir]] forests of the [[Rocky Mountains]], though like ''A. brunneofibrillosus'', it shows a clear preference for growth on deep leaf litter.<ref name=Kuo2007/>

''[[Agaricus pattersoniae]]'' closely resembles ''A. fuscofibrillosus'' but is larger and the cap has appressed brown squamules and is not fibrillose.  ''A. brunneofibrillosus'' is also similar to  ''[[Agaricus fuscovelatus|A. fuscovelatus]]'', but that species has a more conical cap with brownish scales, and a dark brown ring.

==Habitat and distribution==

Fruit bodies appear in the late fall and winter, where they grow scattered or in groups in deep [[leaf litter]] under [[Monterey cypress]]es or rarely under other trees.<ref name=Arora1986/> The mushroom is found in coastal [[California]] and is most common in the [[Monterey Bay Area|Monterey]] and [[San Francisco Bay Area]]s.
